author: Andrea Crothers
title: Longreach Pastoral College marks 50 years
text:
Map: Longreach 4730 
One of the best known agricultural training institutions in the country, the Longreach Pastoral College, turned 50 on Monday. 
The college opened in 1967 to deliver basic skills to young graziers, and 50 years on to the day, the college welcomed its newest cohort of students. 
It started out as a bold concept between some Longreach graziers and the council to establish the university of the outback. 
It was 1965 and the township did not even have a high school yet, but there was local consensus that an institution was needed. 
The chance came when then-education minister Jack Pizzey visited nearby Winton, and brothers Sir James and Lloyd Walker jumped in the car to go make their case. 
Sir James's daughter and current college board member Rosemary Champion said it was a four-hour trek along a dirt road. 
"When they arrived there, Jack Pizzey said 'Well, what do you two cowboys want?'" Ms Champion said. 
The brothers told him they wanted to "build a university in the outback". 
Armed with 40 hectares of land and an amount of money in mind to establish the college, the Walkers' request was granted, with the minister signing off on the project on the spot. 
Eighteen months later, on February 6, 1967, the doors opened for the college's first intake of students. 
"It was a great day for the outback," Ms Champion said. 
She said the college was in such high demand that only one in five applicants were admitted. 
"They flocked to us, because â€¦ really it is the first and only college that specialises particularly in sheep and wool production in the semi-arid rangelands, broadacre in the world," Ms Champion said. 
"And of course it's evolved through all animal livestock, particularly cattle and particularly horses now too." Letting girls through the door 
Perhaps one of the greatest changes came in 1980 when females were allowed to enrol in what was a strictly all-male institution. 
"There wasn't even a thought that women could be in ag back then," Ms Champion said. 
"A group of women thought 'This is just not good enough, you know, ag is for everybody, we're all girls on the land'." 
The women formed a coordinating body and approached the college board, before convincing the reluctant student council things needed to change. 
Today, about 80 per cent of students are female. Photo: Longreach Pastoral College was an all-male institution when it opened in 1967. (ABC Western Queensland: Andrea Crothers) Bright future for college 
As the college celebrates its 50th anniversary, board chairman Richard Pietsch said it was a significant milestone for the institution. 
"Fifty years of doing anything and still being operating is great," Mr Pietsch said. 
"It's cause for real celebration that we're still up and running, and we're successfully training students." 
Mr Pietsch said the future was bright for the college, particularly with the prospect of large numbers of sheep returning to western Queensland . 
"It's a wonderful time to be in agriculture," he said. 
"We're now actually making real money and we're being able to put that back into infrastructure and all sorts of things as producers, and also into the training of people we use and need in industry." Photo: New students Laura Greenfield, of Marree, South Australia, and Chelsea Kerr, of Kingaroy, on their first day of college. (ABC Western Queensland: Andrea Crothers) New students start learning 
This week the college once again welcomed students from across the country for the start of the college year. 
Laura Greenfield made the 1,500-kilometre trek from Marree in South Australia to study a certificate III in horse breeding and training. 
She was attracted by the opportunities for working with horses and all the facilities the college provided. 
Chelsea Kerr, from Kingaroy, is one of many students starting one of the college's most recent courses, the Northern Beef Industries Program. 
Ms Kerr said the hands-on approach at the college suited her learning. 
"It's a prac-based course and it gives you the skills you'll need to go off on a station or pursue a career in the ag industry," she said. 
With the historic year in the college's history now underway, Ms Champion said it was just what the founders would have hoped for. 
"These young people that we're educating now, as we did back then, is to get on the big stations and make them work ready," she said. 
"I think my dad, his brother Lloyd, and John Hoist-Lewis, I think they'd be incredibly proud."
